'''''Suillellus luridus''''' (formerly '''''Boletus luridus'''''), commonly known as the '''lurid bolete''', is a [[fungus]] of the [[Boletaceae]] family, found in [[calcareous]] [[broad-leaved tree|broadleaved woodlands]] in [[Europe]]. [[Basidiocarp|Fruit bodies]] appear in summer and autumn and may be locally abundant. It is a firm bolete with an olive-brown [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] up to {{convert|20|cm|in|0|abbr=on}} in diameter, with small orange or red [[Hymenophore|pores]] on the underside (yellow when young). The stout ochre [[stipe (mycology)|stem]] reaches {{convert|8|–|14|cm|in|0|abbr=on}} high and {{convert|1|–|3|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} wide, and is patterned with a red network. Like several other red-pored boletes, it stains blue when bruised or cut.

[[edible mushroom|Edible]] and good when cooked. It can cause [[Foodborne illness|gastric upset]] when eaten raw and can be confused with the [[poisonous mushroom|poisonous]] ''[[Boletus satanas]]''; as a result, some guidebooks recommend avoiding consumption altogether. When consumed with alcohol, ''Suillellus luridus'' has been implicated in causing adverse reactions similar to those caused by the compound [[coprine]], though laboratory testing has not revealed any evidence of coprine in the mushroom.

First described in 1774, the species has been transferred to various Boletaceae genera in its [[Taxonomy (biology)|taxonomic]] history, although it retained the original name given to it by German botanist [[Jacob Christian Schaeffer]] until a transfer to genus ''[[Suillellus]]'' in 2014. Several [[variety (botany)|varieties]], a [[subspecies]], and a [[form (botany)|form]] have been described by European mycologists. ''Suillellus luridus'' is [[mycorrhiza]]l, forming a [[symbiosis|symbiotic]] association with [[broad-leaved tree]]s trees as [[oak]], [[chestnut]], [[birch]] and [[beech]], and has been found to have a growth-enhancing effect on [[conifer]]s in experiments. The fruit bodies are highly attractive to, and often infested by, insects, and several species of [[diptera|fly]] have been recorded [[mycophagy|feeding]] on them. Chemical analyses have revealed some aspects of the mushroom's components, including its [[Volatility (chemistry)|volatile]] flavour compounds, its [[fatty acid]] and [[amino acid]] compositions, and the identities of the [[carotenoid]] compounds responsible for its colour.

==Taxonomy and phylogeny==

''Boletus luridus'' was [[species description|described]] by German botanist [[Jacob Christian Schäffer]] in 1774, in his series on fungi of [[Bavaria]] and the [[Palatinate (region)|Palatinate]], ''Fungorum qui in Bavaria et Palatinatu circa Ratisbonam nascuntur icones.''<ref name="Schaeffer 1774"/> The [[botanical name|specific epithet]] is the [[Latin]] adjective ''luridus'', '[[wikt:sallow|sallow]]'.<ref name="Nilper 1977"/> French botanist [[Jean Baptiste François Pierre Bulliard|Pierre Bulliard]]'s 1791 ''Boletus rubeolarius''<ref name="Bulliard 1791"/> is a heterotypic [[synonym (biology)|synonym]] (based on a different [[type (biology)|type]]).<ref name="urlFungorum synonymy: Suillellus luridus"/> The following year, [[Johann Friedrich Gmelin]] called it ''Boletus subvescus'',<ref name="Gmelin 1792"/> from the Latin words ''sub'' "nearly" or "under",<ref name= "Simpson 1854"/> and ''vescus'' "edible".<ref name="Nilper 1977a"/> However, this is a ''[[nomen nudum]]''.<ref name="urlMycoBank: Boletus subvescus"/>  Several [[Taxonomy (biology)|taxonomical]] synonyms arose when the species was transferred to different genera within the family [[Boletaceae]] by different authorities, including ''[[Leccinum]]'' by [[Samuel Frederick Gray]] in 1821,<ref name="Gray 1821"/> ''Tubiporus'' by [[Petter Karsten]] in 1881,<ref name="Karsten 1881"/> ''Dictyopus'' by [[Lucien Quélet]] in 1888,<ref name="Quélet 1886"/> and ''Suillellus'' by [[William Murrill]] in 1909.<ref name="urlFungorum synonymy: Suillellus luridus"/><ref name="Murrill 1909"/>
[[File:Netzstieliger Hexenröhrling-1.jpg|thumb|left|1897 illustration by Albin Schmalfuß]]
The [[variety (botany)|variety]] ''Boletus luridus'' var. ''erythropus'', published as "beta" by [[Elias Magnus Fries]] in his 1821 ''[[Systema Mycologicum]]'',<ref name="Fries 1821"/> is synonymous with ''[[Boletus erythropus]]''.<ref name="urlMycoBank: Boletus erythropus"/> ''Boletus luridus'' var. ''rubriceps'' was originally described from Spain (as a species of ''Tubiporus'') by [[René Maire]] in 1937,<ref name="Maire 1937"/> and later formally transferred to ''Boletus'' by [[Aurel Dermek]] in 1987.<ref name="Dermek 1987"/> Other varieties of ''B. luridus'' include Roman Schulz's var. ''obscurus'' and var. ''rubromaculatus'' published in 1924;<ref name="Michael 1924"/> [[Josef Velenovský]]'s 1939 var. ''tenuipes'', found in the Czech Republic;<ref name="Velenovský 1939"/> and Jean Blum's 1969 var. ''lupiniformis'' and var. ''queletiformis'', originally described from France and Spain, respectively.<ref name="Index of Fungi"/> ''Boletus erythrentheron'', originally described as a distinct species by Jan Bezděk, was later recombined as the variety ''B. luridus'' var. ''erythrentheron'' by [[Albert Pilát]] and Dermek in 1979,<ref name="Dermek 1979"/> and finally as a [[subspecies]] by Jiri Hlavácek in 1995.<ref name="Hlavácek 1995"/> Carmine Lavorato and Giampaolo Simonini defined the [[form (botany)|form]] ''primulicolor'' from [[Sardinia]] in 1997.<ref name="Lavorato 1997"/> Rolf Singer's 1947 variety ''caucasicus'', later recombined as an independent species, ''[[Boletus caucasicus]]'' Singer ex. Alessio,<ref name="urlFungorum: Boletus caucasicus"/> has never been validly published  and is a ''[[nomen nudum]]''.<ref name="Vizzini et al. 2014"/> ''Boletus luridus'' f. ''sinensis'', found in [[Hainan Province]], China, was later elevated to species status and transferred to another genus with the name ''[[Neoboletus sinensis]]''.<ref name="Lei 2009"/>

''Boletus luridus'' was the [[type species]] of ''Boletus'' [[section (biology)|section]] ''Luridi'', originally circumscribed by Fries in 1838.<ref name="Fries 1838"/> This section traditionally included species producing medium to large fruit bodies with thick, swollen stems, and minute pores that are coloured red, orange, or rarely yellow.<ref name="Snell 1970"/> However, early [[phylogenetic]] investigations indicated that ''[[Boletus]]'' is strongly [[paraphyletic]] in its traditional delimitation. As further studies have resolved phylogenetic and taxonomical relationships to a finer detail, ''Boletus'' has been fragmented and additional genera were recognised. [[Molecular phylogenetics]] inferred from [[ribosomal DNA]] sequences by Manfred Binder and [[David Hibbett]], showed ''B. luridus'' to be related to a group containing ''[[Boletus torosus|B. torosus]]'' and ''[[Boletus luteocupreus|B. luteocupreus]]'' (now placed in genus ''[[Imperator]]''), with ''[[Boletus vermiculosus|B. vermiculosus]]'' and ''[[Pulveroboletus ravenelii]]'' as more distant relatives.<ref name="urlBinderHibbett2004"/> In a separate molecular study by Mello and colleagues,<ref name="Mello 2006"/> ''B. luridus'' clustered together with ''[[Boletus rhodoxanthus|B. rhodoxanthus]]'', while further genetic analyses in 2013 indicated that ''B. luridus'' and some red-pored boletes are part of a ''dupainii'' clade (named after ''[[Boletus dupainii]]''), quite distant from the core group of ''[[Boletus edulis]]'' and its relatives.<ref name="Nuhn 2013"/> However, more refined analyses based on a larger number of sequences, have since demonstrated that ''B. luridus'' and its allied species form a distinct generic [[clade]],<ref name="Wu 2014"/> and since 2014 the fungus has been placed in genus ''[[Suillellus]]''.<ref name="Vizzini 2014"/>

===Common names===
The English [[common name]] is lurid bolete.<ref name="urlRecommended English Names for Fungi"/> Both ''S. luridus'' and ''[[Boletus satanas]]'' are known as ''ayimantari'' (meaning "bear mushroom"), in Eastern Turkey.<ref name="Demirel 2004"/>

==Description==
{{multiple image
| align     = right
| image1    = Boletus luridus 60184.jpg
| width1    = {{#expr: (100 * 750 / 500) round 0}}
| caption1  = Closeup of the pore surface. Note the yellow region around the margin and the blue discolouration where the cap has been handled.
| image2    = Boletus luridus 60183.jpg
| width2    = {{#expr: (100 * 750 / 496) round 0}}
| caption2  = The stem has orange-red reticulation over a yellowish background and bruises blue.
}}
''Suillellus luridus'' is a stout fungus with a thick yellow-olive to olive-brown convex cushion-shaped [[Pileus (mycology)|cap]] that can reach {{convert|20|cm|in|0|abbr=on}} in diameter.<ref name="Haas 1969"/> The cap colour tends to darken with age, and regions of red, orange, purple, brown, or olive-green can often be present.<ref name="Alessio 1985"/> The cap surface is finely [[tomentose]] (velvety) at first, becoming smoother with old age, and viscid in wet weather.<ref name="Zeitlmayr l976"/> The [[hymenium|pore surface]] is initially yellowish-orange or orange, before turning orange-red to sometimes red and stains strongly blue when injured or handled.<ref name="Bessette 2000"/><ref name="Munoz 2005"/> The pore surface usually has a lighter-coloured zone encircling the margin, as the pores tend to darken from their point of attachment to the stem outwards.<ref name="Alessio 1985"/><ref name="Galli 2007"/> There are 2–3 rounded pores per millimetre, and the [[Hymenophore|tubes]] are {{convert|1|–|2|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name="Bessette 2000"/> The tubes are shorter around the cap margin and close to the [[Stipe (mycology)|stem]], where they form a circular depression. Initially pale yellow, the tubes gradually become olive-yellow and stain bluish-green upon exposure to air.<ref name="Alessio 1985"/> A frequent feature is the presence of a [[maroon (color)|maroon]] layer between the tubes and the [[trama (mycology)|flesh]] (known as Bataille’s line),<ref name="Michell 2006"/> but this is not always present and subhymenial flesh can occasionally be yellow or straw-coloured.<ref name="Vizzini et al. 2014"/> The stem is {{convert|8|–|14|cm|in|0|abbr=on}} tall and {{convert|1|–|3|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} wide, and bears a distinctive, elongated (or "stretched") orange-red reticulum (network) pattern on a paler yellowish, orange, or ochre background, often becoming darker and vinaceous towards the base.<ref name="Phillips 2006"/><ref name="Galli 2007"/> The flesh is yellowish, sometimes with red patches in the cap but almost always rhubarb to vinaceous-red towards the stem base, and stains an intense dark blue when bruised or cut. There is a faint sour smell, and the taste is described as mild.<ref name="Haas 1969"/><ref name="Zeitlmayr l976"/> The [[mycelium]] is an unusual yellow colour.<ref name="Ramsbottom 1953"/>

Variety ''queletiformis'' can be distinguished from the main form by the reddish discolouration of the stem base that occurs both on the exterior surface and in the flesh.<ref name="Siquier 2008"/> Variety ''rubriceps'' has a deep crimson red cap, while var. ''lupiniformis'' has a pale yellow or dirty ochre cap and pores, sometimes with pink tones throughout.<ref name="Alessio 1985"/>
[[File:2009-10-09 Boletus luridus Schaeff 60182.jpg|150px|thumb|right|Spores]]
The [[spore print]] is [[olive (color)|olive]] to brownish olive. Under the [[optical microscope|microscope]], the spores are elliptical to somewhat fusiform (spinde-shaped), measuring 11–15 [[micrometre|μm]] long by 4.5–6.5 μm wide and have a median spore quotient of 2.2.<ref name="Phillips 2006"/><ref name="Vizzini et al. 2014"/> The [[basidia]] (spore-bearing cells) are club-shaped and four-spored, and measure 29.2–36.5 by 11.0–12.4 μm. [[Cystidia]] on the sides of the tubes (pleurocystidia) are fuse-shaped with swollen middles and long necks, measuring 33–48 by 7.3–13.5 μm; cheilocystidia (on the edges of the pores) have a similar [[morphology (biology)|morphology]]. The [[cap cuticle]] is made of cylindrical hyphae 3.7–5.8 μm wide that are interwoven compactly, and the hyphal tips are erect and arranged in bundles. In contrast, the hyphae of the cap flesh is loosely interwoven with hyphae that are cylindrical and branched, measuring 3.7–8.8 μm. Hyphae do not contain [[clamp connection]]s.<ref name="Ammirati 1985"/>

Some [[Chemical tests in mushroom identification|chemical tests]] can be used to help identify the mushroom. A drop of dilute [[potassium hydroxide]] placed on the cap cuticle will stain dark red to blackish, and orange-yellow on the flesh,<ref name="Bessette 2000"/> while [[ferrous sulphate]] solution turns the cuticle yellow and then greenish-yellow.<ref name="Dickinson 1982"/> [[Melzer's reagent]] will turn the flesh dark blue, after the natural bluing reaction to injury has faded.<ref name="Bessette 2000"/>

===Similar species===

''[[Suillellus mendax]]'', a species described from [[Italy]] in 2014<ref name="Vizzini et al. 2014"/> and subsequently confirmed in [[Cyprus]] and [[France]],<ref name="Loizides 2019"/> is very similar to ''S. luridus'' and found under the same host-trees. It produces more robust fruit bodies with a markedly tomentose cap, has a reticulum that is less pronounced and often restricted to the upper part of the stem, and is mostly found on acidic rather than calcareous soil. Microscopically, ''[[Suillellus mendax|S. mendax]]'' has more elongated, narrowly fusiform (spinde-shaped) spores than ''S. luridus'', measuring (12.4–)13.3–14.7(–15.5) × (4.5–)4.9– 5.5(–5.7) μm, and with a higher spore quotient of 2.7. Collections from [[southern Europe]] previously classified as ''[[Boletus caucasicus]]'' on the basis of a yellow subhymenial layer (the flesh in the cap tissue immediately above the tube layer known as Bataille’s line),<ref name="Loizides 2011"/> have been shown to phylogenetically correspond to either ''S. luridus'' or ''S. mendax''.<ref name="Loizides 2019"/> As shown by Vizzini and colleagues,<ref name="Vizzini et al. 2014"/> the name ''Boletus caucasicus'' has been invalidly published (''[[nomen nudum]]'') and the Bataille's line is not reliable for discriminating between species in the ''Luridi'' complex, as it can be randomly present or absent in both ''S. luridus'' and ''[[Suillellus mendax|S. mendax]]''.

Another similar species is ''[[Suillellus comptus]]'', a [[Mediterranean]] [[bolete]] sharing a lot of features with ''S. luridus'' and ''[[Suillellus queletii|S. queletii]]''.<ref name="Simonini 1992"/> This uncommon species is also found on [[calcareous|chalky]] soil under [[Quercus|oak]], but generally produces more slender and dull-coloured fruit bodies, with a rudimentary, incomplete, or at times completely absent reticulation, rarely extending below the top (apex) of the stem. Under the [[optical microscope|microscope]], ''S. comptus'' has very similar spores to ''S. luridus'', but the [[hyphae]] of its [[cap cuticle]] are more loose and prostrate, running more or less parallel to the [[cap]].<ref name="Munoz 2005"/><ref name="Vizzini et al. 2014"/> Also in the same genus, ''[[Suillellus queletii]]'' shares with ''S. luridus'' a vinaceous stem base and strongly bluing flesh, but completely lacks reticulation on the stem.

The edible ''[[Neoboletus luridiformis]]'' can be distinguished from ''S. luridus'' by its dark brown cap and absence of any reticulation on the stem; it also grows on sandy soils associated with conifers.<ref name="Haas 1969"/> In genus ''[[Rubroboletus]]'', ''[[Rubroboletus satanas|R. satanas]]'' is also found on [[calcareous|chalky]] soils, but produces larger and more robust fruit bodies with a pale cap and differently patterned reticulation to ''S. luridus''.<ref name="Haas 1969"/><ref name="Munoz 2005"/> Its flesh does not turn blue so intensely on bruising or cutting, while overripe mushrooms often carry a smell of decay.<ref name="Lamaison 2005"/> Another red-pored species in this genus, ''[[Rubroboletus rhodoxanthus]]'', has characteristic pinkish tones in the cap and a very dense, differently patterned reticulation. When longitudinally cut, its flesh is bright yellow in the stem and stains blue only in the cap.<ref name="Michell 2006"/><ref name="Galli 2007"/>

A number of extra-European [[boletes]] share a similar appearance with ''S. luridus'' and have been a source of confusion in past. ''[[Boletus hypocarycinus|Suillellus hypocarycinus]]'' (found in North America) and ''[[Boletus subvelutipes]]'' (reported from North America and Asia and of yet unclear phylogenetic placement), can be somewhat similar, but lack reticulation on the stem.<ref name="Bessette 2000"/> Initially collected in [[Michigan]] under oak,  ''[[Boletus vinaceobasis]]'' resembles ''S. luridus'', but has shorter spores and its cystidia are dark brown in Melzer's reagent.<ref name="SmithThiers1971"/> This species' phylogenetic position also remains unresolved. Also in North America, ''[[Rubroboletus pulcherrimus]]'' can be somewhat similar, but has a more robust stem and deeper red pores.<ref name="Arora 1986"/> The Chinese species ''[[Neoboletus sinensis]]'', originally described as a form of ''S. luridus'' but now placed in a different genus, has considerably larger spores, reported to reach 12–17 by 5.5–7 μm.<ref name="Lei 2009"/> Collections closely resembling ''S. luridus'' have also been recorded in Australia, though later renamed ''[[Boletus barragensis]]'' as they differ in spore size and a preference for trees of the family [[Myrtaceae]].<ref name="Watling 1999"/><ref name="Grgurinovic 1997"/>

==Ecology and distribution==
The fungus grows in a [[mycorrhiza]]l association with [[broad-leaved tree]]s such as [[oak]] (''Quercus''), [[birch]] (''Betula''), [[chestnut]] (''Castanea'') and [[beech]] (''Fagus''), on chalky (calcareous) soils.<ref name="Haas 1969"/><ref name="Vizzini et al. 2014"/><ref name="Loizides 2019"/> In the Czech Republic, the variety ''rubriceps'' has been reported growing under [[Tilia|linden]] (''Tilia'').<ref name="Tichy 1998"/> It is also suspected of being a mycorrhizal associate of [[subshrub]] [[rock rose]]s in the genus ''[[Helianthemum]]''.<ref name="Barden 2007"/>

Field studies indicate that the fungus, when paired as a mycorrhizal partner with seedlings of the conifer ''[[Cunninghamia|Cunninghamia lanceolata]]'', increases the seedling's survival rate, augments its height and ground diameter, and increases the [[chlorophyll]] content in the leaves.<ref name="Wang 2006"/> A similar growth-enhancing effect had been noted earlier with ''[[Pinus taiwanensis]]'' seedlings.<ref name="Hu 1981"/> These beneficial effects on plant growth are a result of multiple interactions among the fungus, host plant, and indigenous soil microbes that increase the [[biomass (ecology)|biomass]] of [[carbon]], and increase the bacterial [[biodiversity|diversity]] in the [[mycorrhizosphere]].<ref name="Zhang 2010"/> In a study comparing the [[Halotolerance|salinity resistance]] of three common ectomycorrhizal fungi (the others were ''[[Suillus bovinus]]'' and ''[[Suillus luteus|S. luteus]]''), ''S. luridus'' was the most tolerant to high concentrations of salt, and is a good candidate species for the inoculation of tree seedlings to be planted on saline soil.<ref name="Sheng 2009"/>  Fruit bodies grow singly or scattered on the ground,<ref name="Bessette 2000"/> from June to November after summer rains. ''S. luridus'' may occur in parks near a single tree, though it is very rarely found in [[soil pH|acidic soils]].<ref name="Haas 1969"/>
[[File:Boletus luridus 239809.jpg|thumb|left|A collection from Austria]]
The predilection of insects for this mushroom was noted by 19th-century British mycologist [[Anna Maria Hussey]], who wrote in 1847: <blockquote>there are very few of the soft-fleshed tribes, all of which are the nurseries of innumerable insects, so much in favour as the poisonous ''Boletus luridus'', on breaking an old one it is a living mass of larvae. Our present subject is so soon attacked by insects that it is very rare to find specimens devoid of wriggling life, and being a very common and abundant kind, it must be of great service in the economy of insect existence.<ref name="Hussey 1847"/></blockquote> Several fly species have been recorded [[mycophagy|feeding]] on the fruit bodies, including ''[[Phaonia boleticola]]'', ''[[Phaonia rufipalpis|P. rufipalpis]]'', ''[[Thricops diaphanus]]'',<ref name="Skidmore 1985"/> and, in North America, ''[[Drosophila falleni]]'', ''[[Pegomya mallochi]]'', ''[[Pegomya winthemi|P. winthemi]]'', ''[[Megaselia pygmaeoides]]'', and ''[[Muscina assimilis]]''.<ref name="Wheeler 1984"/> In contrast, [[slug]]s tend to avoid consuming this species.<ref name="Elliot 1922"/>

Based on [[phylogenetic]]ally verified collections and belowground [[DNA]] studies of [[mycelia]]l distribution, the fungus appears to be native to [[Europe]] and has been so far documented in [[Austria]], [[Cyprus]], [[Denmark]], [[Estonia]], [[France]], [[Italy]], [[Montenegro]] and [[Sweden]].<ref name="Iotti 2005"/><ref name="Nygren 2007"/><ref name="Krpata 2008"/><ref name="Osmundson 2013"/><ref name="Vizzini et al. 2014"/><ref name="Loizides 2019"/> Its distribution may extend east to the [[Black Sea]] and eastern [[Anatolia]] regions of [[Turkey]],<ref name="Demirel 2004"/><ref name="Sesli 2007"/> and south to the Bar'am Forest in the [[Upper Galilee]] region of northern [[Israel]],<ref name="Avizohar 1972"/> although these reports are in need of molecular verification.

A number of extra-European reports can be found in literature predating [[DNA]] studies, ranging from [[India]]<ref name="Kumar 2011"/> and [[Pakistan]],<ref name="Sarwar 2007"/> to [[Canada]],<ref name="Ammirati 1985"/> the [[United States]],<ref name="Stack 1981"/> [[Mexico]],<ref name="Montoya 2004"/><ref name="Pérez-Moreno 2008"/> [[Costa Rica]],<ref name="urlHalling"/> [[China]]<ref name="Zhishu 1993"/> and [[Taiwan]],<ref name="Hu 1981"/> but these have not been confirmed by molecular testing and are more likely to represent similar, misidentified taxa.<ref name="Wu 2014"/><ref name="Wu et al. 2016"/>

==Toxicity/Edibility==
Mild tasting, ''Suillellus luridus'' is often reported as edible after thorough cooking. It is highly regarded in France,<ref name="Haas 1969"/><ref name="Lamaison 2005"/> while it is commonly consumed in Italy, Czechia and Slovakia as well as other parts of Europe.<ref name="Rubel 2008"/> However, caution is advised if choosing this species for consumption, as it resembles some poisonous blue-staining boletes and some guidebooks recommend avoiding it altogether.<ref name="Nilper 1977"/> If eaten raw or insufficiently cooked, symptoms of [[Foodborne illness|gastrointestinal poisoning]] can occur within 30 minutes to two hours, including  nausea, vomiting, abdominal  cramps,  and diarrhoea. A full recovery can be expected within 24 to 48 hours if fluid losses are restored.<ref name="Tomalak 2011"/>

''Suillellus luridus'' has been suspected of causing an enhanced alcohol sensitivity similar to that caused by the common ink cap (''[[Coprinopsis atramentaria]]''), with gastric symptoms. A German mycologist reported having suffered symptoms himself upon imbibing alcohol with this "otherwise excellent" mushroom.<ref name="Zeitlmayr l976"/><ref name="Flammer 1985"/> A 1982 report of three cases from Switzerland further incriminated the species,<ref name="Benjamin 1995"/> yet a 1994 study casts doubt on this; researchers Ulrich Kiwitt and Hartmut Laatsch looked for [[antabuse]]-like compound [[coprine]] content in ''S. luridus'' and similar species, and found none in the historical suspect but did find indications for it in the rare ''[[Imperator torosus]]''. They concluded that the most likely explanation for historical incidents was a misidentification of ''B. torosus'' with ''S. luridus'', though they could not rule out ''S. luridus'' containing a hitherto unidentified compound causing alcohol-related reactions.<ref name="Kiwitt 1994"/>

==Chemistry==
[[File:Boletus luridus 62499.jpg|thumb|right|Several carotenoids are responsible for the various colours of the cap, tubes, and stem, while variegatic and xerocomic acid cause the bluing reaction that occurs with tissue injury.]]
The composition of the [[Volatility (chemistry)|volatile]] flavour compounds of ''Suillellus luridus'' consists largely of [[linoleic acid]], with smaller proportions of [[1-butanol]], [[3-methyl-1-butanol]], [[pentadecanoic acid]], [[palmitic acid]], linoleic acid [[Fatty acid methyl ester|methyl ester]], and [[heptadecanoic acid]]. [[Pyrazine]] compounds might be responsible for the characteristic odour of the dried mushroom.<ref name="Li 2009"/> The predominant [[sterol]] present in the fruit bodies is [[ergosterol]], with smaller amounts of closely related [[derivative (chemistry)|derivative]] compounds.<ref name="De Simone 1979"/> The main [[fatty acid]]s of the mushroom include linoleic acid (53.4% of total fatty acids), [[oleic acid]] (24.1%), and palmitic acid (10.2%). [[Arginine]] is the free [[amino acid]] found in the highest concentration (96.9 [[Mole (unit)|μM]] per gram of [[dry matter|dry weight]]), followed by [[glutamine]] (9.7) and [[alanine]] (8.2).<ref name="Dembitsky 2010"/>

The [[carotenoid]] content of the fruit bodies differs substantially between the cap, the tubes, and the stem. The upper part of the cap, which contains 3.1 [[microgram]]s of carotenoid per gram (µg/g) fresh weight, has predominantly [[mutatochrome]] (47% of total carotenoids), [[alpha-Carotene|4-keto-α-carotene]] (40.2%), and [[δ-carotene]] (6.4%). The major carotenoids in the tubes (totaling 4.3 µg/g) include [[neurosporaxanthin]] (31.1%), [[auroxanthin]] (17.2%), 4-keto-α-carotene (17.1%),  and [[rhodopin]] (15.8%). The stem (1.2 µg/g) contains primarily auroxanthin (32.5%), followed by 4-keto-α-carotene (19.9%), [[Beta-zeacarotene|β-zeacarotene]] (18.5%), and rhodopin (11.4%).<ref name="Czezuga 1978"/> The colour change observed with tissue injury is caused by [[variegatic acid|variegatic]] and [[xerocomic acid]]s, both of which turn blue when [[oxidative enzyme|oxidized enzymatically]] upon exposure to air.<ref name="Nelson 2010"/>
